column1: '''''The Notion Club Papers''''' is the title of an abandoned novel by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]
column2: written during [[1945]] and published posthumously in ''[[Sauron Defeated]]''
column3: the 9th volume of ''[[The History of Middle-earth]]''. It is a space/time/dream travel story
column4: written at the same time as ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' was being developed.

column1: The story itself involves the minutes of the meetings of an arts discussion club at [[Oxford]]
column2: a fictionalization of (and a pun on) Tolkien's own Club
column4: [[Alwin Arundel Lowdham]] discusses his lucid dreams about "[[Atlantis]]"; through these dreams
column5: he "discovers" much about the [[Númenor]] story and the languages of the [[Elder Days]] (notably [[Quenya]]
column7: and [[Adûnaic]] — the last very interesting since it is the sole source of most of the material on this language). While not finished
column8: at the end of the given story it becomes clear Lowdham himself is a reincarnation of sorts of [[Elendil]]. (''Alwin'' is a modernisation of the name ''[[Ælfwine]]''
column10: or ''Elendil'' in Quenya.)  Other members of the Club also mention their vivid dreams of other times and places.

column1: Tolkien not only created fictional meetings for these papers; he also created a fictional history for the manuscript of the papers. According to the papers
column2: the meetings occurred in the 1980s; they even mention events that occurred in the 1970s and 1980s. About one-fourth of the papers were found among sacks of waste paper in 2012 at Oxford by a Mr. Green. Mr. Green published a first edition containing excerpts from these papers
column3: indicating that they were written during the 1980s by one of the participants. Two scholars read the first edition
column5: and then submitted a full report. The "Notes to the Second Edition" mentions the contradictory evidence in dating the manuscripts
column6: and an alternative date is presented: they may have been written in the 1940s.

column1: These papers remind one of [[C.S. Lewis]]' commentary to Tolkien's poem ''[[Lay of Leithian]]''
column2: in which Lewis created a fictional history of scholarship of the poem and even referred to other manuscript tradition to recommend changes to the poem.

column1: ''The Notion Club Papers'' may be seen as an attempt to re-write ''[[The Lost Road]]''
column2: published and discussed in ''[[The Lost Road and Other Writings]]''
column3: as being another attempt to tie the Númenórean legend in with a more modern tale.  There is
column5: no direct connection between the modern settings of the two stories within the fictional frame.

column1: ''The Notion Club Papers'' includes a mention of a "mechanical nightingale"; it has been suggested that this is a reference to [[Wikipedia:Hans Christian Andersen|Hans Christian Andersen]]'s story "[http://www.surlalunefairytales.com/nightingale/index.html The Nightingale]". Andersen was inspired to write the story after having been infatuated with the singer [[Wikipedia:Jenny Lind|Jenny Lind]] (often called "the Swedish Nightingale").<ref>{{webcite|author='Talelmarhazad' |articleurl=http://greyhavensgroup.wordpress.com/2012/05/21/tolkiens-mechanical-nightingale/|articlename=Tolkien’s Mechanical Nightingale|dated=21 May 2012|website=[http://greyhavensgroup.wordpress.com/ The Grey Havens Group]|accessed=21 May 2012}}</ref>

By an odd coincidence ''The Notion Club Papers'' mentions a great storm occurring during 1987 in England. In real life the [[Wikipedia:Great Storm of 1987|Great Storm of 1987]] occurred in October of that year.
